TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute extends System.Attribute
Public NotInheritable Class UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute Inherits Attribute
public ref class UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute sealed : Attribute

Docs.summary: Suppresses reporting of a specific rule violation, allowing multiple suppressions on a single code artifact.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
<xref:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute> is different than <xref:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.SuppressMessageAttribute> in that it doesn't have a <xref:System.Diagnostics.ConditionalAttribute>. It's always preserved in the compiled assembly.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string category, string checkId) cil managed
Public Sub New (category As String, checkId As String)

Docs.param: The identifier of the analysis rule the attribute applies to.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, specifying the category of the tool and the identifier for an analysis rule.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Category As String
public: property System::String ^ Category { System::String ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the category identifying the classification of the attribute.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
The <xref:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Category> property describes the tool or tool analysis category to which a message suppression attribute applies.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property CheckId As String
public: property System::String ^ CheckId { System::String ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the identifier of the analysis tool rule to be suppressed.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
Concatenated together, the <xref:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Category> and <xref:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.CheckId> properties form a unique check identifier.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Justification { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.Justification : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the justification for suppressing the code analysis message.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ MessageId { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.MessageId : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets an optional argument expanding on exclusion criteria.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
The <xref:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.MessageId> property is an optional argument that specifies additional exclusion where the literal metadata target is not sufficiently precise. For example, the <xref:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute> cannot be applied within a method, and it may be desirable to suppress a violation against a statement in the method that will give a rule violation, but not against all statements in the method.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Scope { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.Scope : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the scope of the code that is relevant for the attribute.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
The `Scope` property is an optional argument that specifies the metadata scope for which the attribute is relevant.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Target { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.Target : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a fully qualified path that represents the target of the attribute.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
The <xref:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Target> property is an optional argument that identifies the analysis target of the attribute. An example value is `System.IO.Stream.ctor():System.Void`. Because it is fully qualified, it can be long, particularly for targets such as parameters. The analysis tool user interface should be capable of automatically formatting the parameter.
